Philip Hammond was on his feet for one hour and two minutes during Wednesday's Budget statement - only the third time in a decade that the speech has lasted over an hour. 
For his second Budget as chancellor, Mr Hammond added six minutes to the statement he delivered in March 2017. 
Just two other Budget addresses in recent times have been longer, and both were delivered by George Osborne: July 2015 (one hour five minutes) and March 2016 (one hour four minutes). 
By contrast, Gordon Brown's final Budget speech in March 2007 lasted just 49 minutes - the shortest since 1979. 
Mr Hammond's speech today is easily eclipsed by the mammoth Budget statements given throughout the 1980s and early 1990s, which regularly approached the two-hour mark. 
But what was actually said? The Mirror have compiled the key takeaways: Tax Fuel duty could rise as Philip Hammond draws up his second Budget (Image: Mirror Online) Income tax tax-free personal allowance increased from £11,500 to £11,850 Threshold for paying 40p income tax raised from £45,000 to £46,350, helping the richest 13% Benefits Chancellor Philip Hammond at the Conservative Party Conference at the Manchester Central Convention Complex in Manchester. (Image: Stefan Rousseau/PA Wire) The six-week waiting time for Universal Credit cut to five weeks in U-turn as part of £1.5billion package UC advances will be worth a full month's pay and repayment period will be doubled from 6 to 12 months Recipients of Housing Benefit to continue to get it for two weeks during transition to Universal Credit Health and social care £10bn package of capital investment in frontline services across this parliament This will be part of Sustainability and Transformation Plans that had demanded billions in cutbacks £2.8bn emergency cash for NHS England - £350m immediately for this winter, £1.6bn in 2018-19, the balance in 2019-20 But this is less than the £4bn demanded by head of the NHS Simon Stevens Promise to provide additional funding for nurses wages' - but based on outcome of talks and no firm promise Not one mention of social care in the 7,704-word speech Read More Smokers fear a second tax rise on tobacco in a year could be announced this week Housing Stamp duty abolished for first-time buyers from TODAY on all homes under £300,000; discount for homes up to £500,000. But Budget experts warn it will simply raise prices and help existing homeowners At least £44 billion of capital funding, loans and guarantees overall over five years to support house-building Target of building 300,000 homes annually to be met "by the mid-2020s" £630 million 'small sites fund' £2.7 billion to more than double the Housing Infrastructure Fund; £400 million for estate regeneration £1.1 billion fund to unlock strategic sites £8 billion of new financial guarantees to support private house-building Additional £34 million to develop construction skills Kensington and Chelsea Council to get extra £28m for mental health services and regeneration support following Grenfell Tower fire Homes left empty could be hit by a 100% council tax premium under powers to be handed to councils Lifting of borrowing caps for councils in high-demand areas to get them building - something they’ve long demanded Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond prepares his Budget speech in his Downing Street office (Image: Getty) Education £177m to give schools £600 for every extra student who takes A-level maths £42m fund will also support £1,000 grants for training teachers in 'fallen behind' areas Freeze on university tuition fees at £9,025 a year Post-2012 students only repay if they earn £25,000 or more Action to stop people overpaying their student loans New £20million fund to allow colleges to prepare for technical ‘T-levels’ Teaching for Mastery of Maths programme will be expanded to thousands more schools Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond will deliver his Autumn Budget on Wednesday (Image: Getty Images) Wages National Living Wage (minimum wage for over-25s) to increase from £7.50 to £7.83 an hour from April 2018 Minimum wage aged 21-24 to rise from £7.05 to £7.38 Minimum wage aged 18-20 to rise from £5.60 to £5.90 Minimum wage aged 16-17 to rise from £4.05 to £4.20 Apprentice wages to rise from £3.50 to £3.70 Cigarettes and alcohol Tobacco escalator to continue at inflation +2%, with additional 1% on hand rolling tobacco Minimum excise duty will also rise Duty on low cost, high strength alcohol - like white ciders - will increase at rate to be confirmed Duties on other ciders, wines, spirits and beer frozen Councils in Derbyshire hit back at mileage claims Vehicles and petrol Driverless cars on the road by 2021 Fuel duty frozen for seventh year in a row Long haul economy rates frozen, paid for with an increase in duties on premium air fares and private jets One-band increase in car tax for older diesels failing to meet emissions tests The existing diesel supplement in company car tax is also going up by one percentage point These two measures will fund a £220m clean air fund Regions Extra £2bn for Scottish Government Extra £1.2bn for Welsh Government Extra £650m for Northern Ireland £337m to replace 40-year-old rolling stock on the Tyne and Wear Metro £1.7billion transforming cities fund, half for 6 areas with elected metro mayors, the other half open for bids £120m for the Redcar steelworks, where the government was accused of failing to do enough Progress is being made on city deals for Tay cities and Stirling Tolls on the Severn Bridge will be abolished by the end of next year The review of how air passenger duty affects Northern Irish tourism will report at the next Budget Some councils in London to be allowed to keep 100% of their business rates in pilot next year Transport 'Millennial railcard' for people aged 26 to 30 Review of airline insolvency arrangements after Monarch collapse Business Package of anti-tax avoidance and evasion measures claimed to raise £4.8bn a year by 2022-23 Includes freezing the 'Indexation allowance' for Capital Gains frozen from January 2018 No change to £85,000 VAT threshold - this is how much turnover firms must make before they must register for VAT. This will net the Treasury £170m a year by 2022/23 Business rates uprating measure to switch from RPI to CPI inflation, which is lower, two years earlier in April 2018. This will cost the Treasury £530m a year by 2019/20 £1,000 tax discount for pubs extended by another year to March 2019 Future business rates reassessments will take place every 3 years, rather than 5 Digital tax: Income tax to be charged on royalties on UK sales that are then passed to low tax countries - raising £200m a year National Productivity Investment Fund to be extended for a further year and expanded to more than £31bn Business leaders in Derbyshire want to know what support firms will get as Britain prepares to leave the EU Brexit Extra £3 billion fund to prepare for a no-deal Brexit to be spent over the next two years Environment A "call for evidence" on whether polystyrene kebab and burger trays, throwaway coffee cups and bubble wrap should be taxed Like us on Facebook
